isis.stitle: EC-17 ANTILOCK TRACTION CONTROLLER - EC-17 INFORMATIONAL INPUTS AND COMMAND OUTPUTS - OUTPUTS

svcproc.title: OUTPUTS
svcproc.para: The Bendix M 22 is the means by which the EC-17 controller modifies driver applied air pressure to the service brakes. The modulator is an electrically controlled air valve located near the service actuator(s) it controls. It is the last valve that air passes through on its way to the brake actuator. A wiring harness connects the modulator to the EC-17 antilock controller. Solenoid valves contained in the modulator provide the electrical interface between the EC-17 controller electronics and the air brake system. The EC-17 is able to simultaneously and independently control four individual modulator assemblies. When vehicle power is supplied to the EC-17, a modulator "chuff" test is performed. When the brake pedal is depressed while the ECU is powered up, the modulator "chuff" test can be heard. This test will verify if the modulator is connected correctly and functional. The modulators will exhaust air in the sequence of rightfront, left front, right rear, and left rear. If they do not follow this sequence, proceed with modulator troubleshooting. Refer to correct pin to pin wiring.
An antilock dash light through an electrical relay is connected to, and controlled by, the EC-17 and serves as a means of advising the driver of the condition of the antilock system.

Two control link connections to the engine or transmission retarder and its relay are provided on the EC-17. One control link or the other can be utilized, but not both on the same vehicle. The hardware for one control link conforms to S.A.E. standard 1708 and the protocol, or coded language used, conforms to S.A.E. standard J1922.

The other control link conforms to S.A.E. standard J1939. Use of a control link allows the EC-17 to temporarily disable the retarder during certain modes of operation. While the EC-17 is capable of this function, and connections are provided, it is not always used. Use of the retarder disable function is not essential but highly recommended for vehicles equipped with a retarder.

note.para: The EC-17 can also disable the retarder using the same S.A.E. J1922 or S.A.E. J1939 protocol it uses to control the traction control, engine torque limiting feature. For this redundant retarder disable to function, the EC-17 must be connected to the engine control module (as would be the case if the EC-17 is programmed for the traction control, torque limiting feature).

svcproc.para: The diagnostic link enables the EC-17 to "report" its operating condition to an external computer using the Bendix diagnostic communications interface hardware in response to certain commands it receives from software like Bendix ACom for Windows. The EC-17 diagnostic link hardware conforms to S.A.E. standard J1708. The protocol, or coded language used, conforms to S.A.E. standard J1587. While connections are provided for this function, it is not always used. The use of the diagnostic link is essential for the servicing and reconfiguration of the EC-17.
If the EC-17 is programmed for traction control, it contains the following outputs:

item.para: A connection to the engine's electronic control module allows the EC-17 to reduce engine torque under certain circumstances.
A traction dash light is connected to and controlled by the EC-17 and serves as a means of advising the driver of the condition of the traction control system.
A connection to the traction solenoid (located in the upper portion of the antilock traction relay valve is provided via a 2 pin Deutsch connector.
